Nasa is to host a major press conference on a "discovery beyond our solar system".

The event will see the revelation of major information about exoplanets, or planets that orbit stars other than our sun, according to a release. It made no further mention of the details of what would be revealed.

Exoplanets are the major hope for life elsewhere in the universe, since many have been found that resemble our own Earth and could have the building blocks of life.

11:16 am

BE11:16am

I'm unclear.

BE11:16am

Anyway, have some sellside to summarise the main points.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

RBC

BE11:17am

Results are broadly in line with expectations and the group has maintained its guidance for FY17. However, the results are still messy with another £71m of one-offs and the outlook is a reminder that 2017 will be a tough year and given 40% of the business is up for rebid through to 2019, there remain many uncertainties. We are unlikely to move operational forecasts today, although EPS will come down for the higher tax rate (50% vs 45% forecast). We continue to struggle with the valuation, with a seemingly significant upturn in trading already being discounted. Whilst there is no question that the business has been stabilized, growth and margin expectations factored into 2018 and beyond look optimistic given the current subdued outlook (particularly in the UK). On 33x FY18E PE, we remain negative, with larger contract wins now key for the business.

BE11:17am

33x 2018 doesn't look great, I admit. But that's the decade-long turnaround shtick I mentioned earlier.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

(@wayneJ: well put. If it were within my remit to agree, I'd probably agree.)

BE11:18am

Morgan Stanley ......

BE11:19am

FY 16 is OK, but FY 2017 guidance is reiterated and there are some high numbers out there, while the front-end loaded pipeline is likely to fall after decision in the next 12mths. EPS is significantly below (due to a volatile tax rate), but the market shouldn’t be focused on that and revenue/EBITA is 1/-1% vs consensus. Net debt is better at £109m (MSe/cons was £148/143m and guidance was less than £150m) and the pipeline is broadly unchanged £8.4bn, but no real improvement vs the c. £8bn at the Dec CMD. 2 factors that affect 2017: 1) 2017e guidance of £65-70m of EBIT compares to MSe £82m, but there are some far higher estimates out there. 2) The pipe is front-end loaded and it is likely to fall as decisions are made in the next 12mths.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Financial position: Net Debt at FY16 of £109m better vs. MSe £148m and its guidance of less than £150m. The underlying leverage ratio is 0.8x vs. covenants of 3.5x and compares to its mid-term target range of 1-2x. Bid Pipeline and Order book - 2017 the pipe likely to fall: The pipeline is broadly at unchanged £8.4bn, but no real improvement vs the c. £8bn at the Dec CMD, and £2.5bn of new contracts were signed in the period. It has £2.5bn of revenue in the order book for FY17 covering 80% of its guidance of £3.1bn and secured orderbook for 2018/19 is £1.7/1.3bn. The pipeline is a 24mth rolling number and is 80% weighted to the next 12 (ie DFRMO, Grafton and 3 x rail in the Middle East) and the overall number is likely to fall as decisions get announced.
Outlook unchanged: Its expectations for 2017 remained unchanged. It continues to expect 2017 revenue of £3.1bn MSe £3.2bn, cons £3bn) and trading profit between £65-70m (MSe £82m, cons £73m), with caution around the sensitivity of its profits to small changes in revenues or costs.

BE11:20am

It could be argued that Serco's down 15% today not because it's surprised in any way, but because Exane's optimism made the consensus look loopy. I'm not 100% convinced by that argument, but it's undeniably an argument.

BE11:21am

Deutsche:

11:21 am
BE11:21am

On our numbers, Serco trades on 2017E EV/EBITA of 26x and EV/sales of 0.6x (-ve FCF, no dividend). The Serco story has focused on management turning the business around and returning to growth 2018E, and it is our view that the market is already pricing in growth and margin improvement. With the pipeline at £8.4bn, 2017E guidance second half weighted and 2018E only 10 months away, we think today's results highlight that there remains a significant amount of work to do and pressure to win contracts.

BE11:24am

PM11:24am

One day, addiction will no longer be viewed through the social lens of scorn and shame. One day, addiction will no longer be a global humanitarian crisis. We at Indivior envision a day in which all patients around the world will have unrestricted access to quality treatments and services for the chronic relapsing conditions and co-morbidities of addiction. Until that day comes, we will continue to pioneer life-transforming treatments. And with the help of healthcare professionals, the public health community, policy makers, payers, and people like you, we will shift public perceptions of these often underserved patient populations, humanize their suffering and medicalize addiction as a chronic, relapsing condition that should be treated similarly to other chronic diseases. Together, we will break down barriers to treatment for millions of people across the globe who need it most.

This is our vision. We are Indivior and we will always focus on you.

11:24 am

(@ELLIOT: it was my impression that antitrust wasn't new news. Am I wrong about that?)

BE11:26am

BE11:26am

And Cantor...........

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Our view: Indivior has enjoyed a very successful 2016 with the opioid addiction franchise benefiting from market share growth, a stable pricing environment and litigation success. Also, the same franchise has shown some significant signs of longevity with positive Phase III data for the depot formulation which should help Indivior transition the franchise from the current film franchise which has been exposed to the spectre of potential generics. We note the increased peak sales projections for the buprenorphine depot formulation but we are less sanguine regarding the outlook for the risperidone monthly depot.
· Strong 2016 as expected – Indivior has delivered a strong 2016 performance with FY sales of $1058m (+4%) compared to BBG consensus of $1067m and adjusted EPS of 34c versus consensus of 35.9c with the key Suboxone film franchise benefiting from a stable pricing environment. At the same time the underlying opioid addiction franchise has enjoyed good growth and Indivior has taken share (currently 61%).
· Ability to invest in pipeline – We also suspect that the financial performance has benefited from a mixed delivery on the rest of the pipeline and this along with better performance elsewhere should allow Indivior to invest in preparation for the launch of the long acting depot formulation (RBP-6000). The company is now in possession of a strong cash position ($692m) which we hope will be used to diversify the pipeline.

BE11:26am

· Guidance for 2017 probably conservative – Guidance for 2017 of revenues of $1050-$1080 compares well to consensus of $1069m and we note that the net income range of $200m-$220m includes $40-$50m “..in driving future organic growth priorities”. Additionally, the company has also increased its peak sales guidance for the depot formulation to at least $1bn (from $400m-$700m) and the risperidone monthly depot. We are fully cognisant of the potential of the depot formulation but are less sanguine regarding the risperidone monthly depot. It is also worth noting that within this increased guidance, Indivior is flagging a slower initial ramp.
· Opioid franchise intact – Our DCF suggests a valuation of 300p and our HOLD recommendation is based on single digit growth profile currently on offer and our desire to see a more diversified product offering outside of opioid addiction.
· Risks – In our recent update (1st February) we noted the excellent performance of the buprenorphine franchise and the growth drivers that are evident which should underpin the franchise but note that the competitive environment for long acting formulations is increasing and mixed delivery on the pipeline to date.

BE11:28am

The final cost may be materially higher than this reserve."

11:36 am
BE11:36am

I've no idea whether it's right, but it makes solid arguments.

BE11:36am

This is Pablo Zuanic, whose work we recommended around SABMiller of course.

BE11:37am

More surprising than KHC bidding for Unilever (a scenario that was clearly among the non-US options) is that they (3G) would walk away, especially if we go by the track record of the BUD branch in the 3G tree. If they indeed miscalculated (we doubt they did), this could have significant implications for the long-term relationship between Warren Buffet and the 3G partners, which could complicate funding for alternative larger deals. We say so if we go by headlines that Warren Buffett (who has seen his combined $9Bn investment in Heinz and Kraft grow to $30Bn) was instrumental in pulling the plug, as a friendly deal could not be reached. But we assume that the bidding parties knew that this was an iconic Commonwealth company, and that Paul Polman is no John Cahill. Given the specificity of the offer (cash and 0.222 of KHC stock), we think negotiations had made it quite far. Advisors knew this could not be a hostile deal, and surely Warren Buffett did not want a hostile and very public fight in the UK. Our (obvious) interpretation is that negotiations broke down, but that they will resume (friendly negotiations). The most logical outcome is that KHC buys the foods/refreshment piece of Unilever, and the rest of the company (Unilever HPC) remains a public entity (or something along those lines: they buy all of Unilever and float the HPC piece). So while other food stocks are up today, we think those gains will be short-lived. We would still expect a friendly rapprochement in the weeks and months ahead.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

The headlines are too ugly to think this was such a poorly managed approach.

KHC made a “private” but rather specific approach for Unilever (cash and 0.222 of its own shares). So this was not the case of “sounding out” the target.

Despite the PR department of KHC saying their “interest was made public at an extremely early stage,” we doubt we were so early in the process.

Unilever apparently was not against a deal, just this deal as structured. It said the offer “fundamentally undervalues Unilever,” that it had “no merit, financial or strategic,” and there was no reason to talk more.

Lazard and the other advisors obviously had to know this would have to be a friendly deal (given the political, regulatory, and dual listings in the UK and AMS, and the role of Warren Buffett), so why would they take the process so far without a better line of sight on the result? Did they miscalculate?

Lazard has advised 3G in most of their recent large-scale transactions, including those at AB InBev. Interestingly, Centerview Partners have been on the other side on all three KHC transactions (advised Heinz, advised Kraft Foods Group, and are now, or were, advising Unilever).

Did Warren Buffett pull the plug when he realized this would need to be a hostile deal for it to be implemented? And was worried about the political and PR implications?

If so, given the bad publicity and headlines, and gross miscalculation, what would this do to the relationship between 3G and Berkshire?

If this were to have a permanent effect on their working and investing relationship (the Omaha/Rio connection), then this should make investors question the potential for other large scale KHC bids for other food companies and for KO (where Berkshire is the largest shareholder).

Berkshire Hathaway’s total Heinz/Kraft investment has grown from $9Bn (he invested $4Bn in the Heinz takeover ex the preferred stock, and then another $5Bn as part of the KRFT deal where he funded half of the one time dividend) to now roughly $30Bn (26.75% x $113Bn). So the relationship must be good.

BE11:38am

A lot of the press seem to want to write "bungled" and suchlike with reference to the approach.

PM11:38am

11:38 am

Finsbury, which is majority owned by WPP, was removed from the Kraft Heinz side by the end of the day.

Crown Ocean Capital P1 Ltd (“Crown Ocean”) the private investment company which is the beneficial
owner of 16.23% of the outstanding ordinary share capital of Bowleven PLC (“Bowleven” or “the
Company”) has, as part of its requisition of a General Meeting of Bowleven to be held on 14 March,
proposed two new and independent directors, namely Mr Eli Chahin and Mr Chris Ashworth.
The proposed directors now make the following statement:
“As proposed independent directors at the Bowleven General Meeting convened for 14 March 2017 we
have made no formal statements to date about the General Meeting, it being a matter for the
shareholders to determine. However, we would wish to state that, if appointed, we would as directors
be acting in the interests of the Company and all its shareholders in accordance with our fiduciary
duties.
“Any suggestion made by Bowleven to the contrary would constitute an event in relation to which we
would reserve our rights to take further action.”

(@Copia, Patience: agreed. Haven't had any suggestion that's happening though.)

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Imperial added to Exane's M&A target list. Surprised it wasn't on before but, hey .....

BE11:53am

JT acquiring Imperial? We believe the time is nigh
Imperial’s likely suitor, Japan Tobacco, is facing challenges it has arguably never faced. With the advance of NGP, JT’s ambitions, access to the US market, a cheap target, organisation changes and compelling deal maths, we believe the time is nigh for a JT-led acquisition of Imperial. We assign a 70% probability of a deal by 2018. There is little or nothing priced in for a takeover of Imperial, with expectations on the trading front firmly grounded. Outperform maintained

BE11:54am

They've said this a lot.

11:54 am
PM11:54am

hehehe

BE11:55am

JT is facing major challenges in some of its big markets
JT is facing significant pressures in both its domestic market (40% of operating profit) and in some of its biggest international markets (the UK, Russia). In the domestic market, JT’s performance is being severely impacted by the expansion of PMI’s iQOS. JT’s business is also under significant pressure in the UK (c.10% of JT’s profit), due to competition in the discount segment (JTI lost 20bps of market share in 2016 but there was a marked deceleration over the year with Q416 down 150bps according to AC Nielsen). In Russia (c.15% of JT’s profit), regulation is weighing on tobacco demand and competition is intensifying.

BE11:55am

Imperial would give Japan Tobacco exposure to the attractive US market JT currently has only very small exposure to the US market through its e-cig brand Logic (#3 with a c.14% share) and has said in the past that they do not want US exposure for fear of litigation risk. Imperial acquired a ~7% share of the US market via disposals from Reynold’s acquisition of Lorillard (Winston, Salem, Kool, Maverick, and the e-cig brand blu), on the top of the 3% market share it already held. Interestingly, as part of the deal, Imperial has negotiated that pre-acquisition litigation risk will stay with Reynolds. Thus, the US business of Imperial is (mostly) litigation free and this has likely not gone unnoticed at JT. Interestingly, JT has recently launched its LD brand in North and South Carolina, perhaps indicating a change of the company’s view towards the US. Acquiring a bigger US presence would allow JT to access the attractive US market (biggest profit pool in the world ex-China, the world’s largest e-cigs market, rational pricing, relatively low pricing, a market which is relatively ‘lighter touch’ on the regulation front), and would allow it to control the Winston brand globally (currently Winston is owned by Imperial in the US and by JT everywhere else). It would also mean that it would gain control of Imperial’s blu in the vapour segment (the #2 brand, with c. 20% share).

11:55 am
BE11:56am

This is all a reiteration, I stress.

BE11:56am

JT cannot acquire Imperial alone Looking at potential anti-trust issues if JT were to acquire Imperial, the UK market
would be clearly an issue. The UK is Imperial’s second biggest market after the US, contributing about 17% of group profits. Imperial holds a 42% market share, an issue considering JT’s 39% market share in the UK. BAT, with a 9% share and with relatively low profits (value-end offering, investment phase) would be the obvious buyer of Imperial UK. BAT has said that bigger UK profits would create tax optimisation opportunities (the cost of running BAT’s global headquarters, based in London, won’t be cheap). The timing for BAT making another acquisition right now is not ideal following its move for Reynolds - net debt / EBITDA at the end of FY18e will be 3.1x on our numbers. This said, we estimate that if BAT acquired Imperial UK at 14x EV/EBIT or GBP8.5bn, it would add only 0.5x to BAT’s net debt / EBITDA ratio. We estimate EPS accretion of around 4%.

BE11:57am

It's only coming back because Exane's added IMB to some list.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

4Q16 numbers are a 6% underlying beat to DBe and 9% vs. consensus, however the quality is mixed: NII (the most important figure in the P&L) was a 2-3% miss to DB and consensus. Other income was a 7% beat, but commentary suggests that this was aided by insurance income which has historically been more volatile / lower quality. Meanwhile operating expenses were around £40-50m better than DB/consensus forecasts, and impairments were a beat. Below the line another £475m of conduct charges were taken in 4Q16, driving a stated PBT miss vs. DBe.

BE11:59am

Lloyds has declared a dividend of 2.55p and a special of 0.5p (so a total of 3.05p for FY16). This compares with consensus at 2.9-3.0p (Factset/Bloomberg) so is a small beat. Meanwhile capital is printed at 13.8%, 10bps ahead of DBe and +20bps vs. consensus. TNAV was in line at 54.8p.

BE11:59am

NIM expected to be greater than 2.70% (pre impact of MBNA, previously guided at 10bps annulised). This compares to DBe 2.75% and cons 2.70%.
Asset quality expected to c.25bps for FY17 (pre MBNA). Consensus is at 29bps, DB 27bps. Given MBNA likely to close in 1H17 this feels in line.
Continue to target cost/income ratio of c.45% exiting 2019 (Dbe is at 46%)
Group expects to generate 170-200bps of CET1 per annum pre dividend. p/f RWAs were £222bn at 4Q so £3.8-£4.4bn of implied earnings (on no RWA growth). Consensus earnings are at £4bn for 2017, £4.4bn for 2018.
Expected RoRE of 12-13.5% and RoTE of 13.5-15% in 2019. The latter compares DBe is at 10% in 2019, consensus 12%. This is materially higher, we expect questions on the call on the assumptions behind this.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Dividends have been delivered, and 4Q16 numbers are a beat, though a mixed quality one in our view given the lower than expected NII. Overall 2017 guidance seems unlikely to move 2017 consensus significantly (asset quality outlook is slightly better than consensus). We expect the focus today to rest on the 2019 RoTE outlook (much higher than DBe and consensus), the assumptions behind it (which imply potential 10-20% higher EPS vs cons depending on equity base), and how this is consistent with 170-200bps generation (which implies £3.7-4.2bn earnings, in line with consensus). Stock is trading at 10.9x 2018e, 1.2x TNAV for a yield of c.5% in 2018.

PM12:00pm

Another warning, strategic review and CMD cancellation
Warning raises concerns about financial reporting

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

This is a profit warning just before the close yesterday.

PM12:01pm

Near the close of trading on Tuesday, NCC issued a second warning on FY17, initiated a strategic review and cancelled the capital markets day (CMD) scheduled for today.
This warning follows that in mid October, followed by the formal reduction of guidance in December. This revised guidance was reiterated on 19 January when H1 results were reported in full.
The trading update within the statement last night referred to a review of Q3 performance and the expected outcome for the full year leading to the board's conclusion that the 'performance of the Assurance Division will be significantly lower than anticipated'. As such, the board expects EBITDA will be c20% below the £45.5-£47.5m previous range. This has led to the board 'initiating a 'comprehensive review of NCC Group's operating strategy'. Given the uncertainty we are not surprised that the CMD (focused on the Assurance business) has been cancelled.

PM12:01pm

In our previous report we indicated that improvement in FCF generation would be key to the investment case. The statement last night vindicated those concerns as well as potentially raising new questions about financial reporting. Given our renewed concerns, we retain our SELL recommendation, lower our estimates and lower our TP to 118p.
At these levels, we believe NCC could become a target for a strategic or financial buyer but any potential buyer would need some clarity on the strategic and financial issues. On our new forecasts, the stock trades on 17.3x 2018 earnings and 10.5x CG adj. EBITDA.

12:01 pm
PM12:01pm

We view the statement as concerning for a number of reasons:
The historic visibility in the Assurance business would suggest reasonable visibility over a six month period and excellent visibility over three months. At the time of the H1 results, the company was two-thirds through the third quarter and should have had excellent visibility through to the full year. The 20% warning is effectively on the final four months of the year. Even if we assume that it equates to 75% of the H2 results (Q4 weighted profits), that is a 50% warning on the remaining profit in the year.
The lateness in reporting ahead of the CMD suggests this is not merely a trading issue but a financial reporting issue. Our concern is that it may affect revenue recognition or cost allocation. This is driven by ongoing concern about the weak cash conversion linked to accrued income.
The company's lowered EBITDA forecast suggests FCF could be negative this financial year, and assuming the current run rate of profitability into FY18, net debt could rise to c2x net/debt EBITDA without a cut in dividends.

PM12:01pm

With this level of uncertainty, we switch our valuation methodology keeping Escrow as a DCF derived value and moving Assurance from a profit multiple to a disposal multiple based on sales (due to the current profit uncertainty). We value Escrow at £1 per share (after central cost allocation) and Assurance at 0.5x-1.0x sales or 18p-36p per share, assuming c£200m of revenue which is a low end valuation for an IT services business. We lower our target price to the lower end of the range, 118p (previously 194p): SELL.

BE12:02pm

NCC released a trading update yesterday afternoon highlighting further issues in its Assurance division. Sales growth has been lower than expected in all regions, resulting in a significant reduction in full year expectations. We have reduced our EPS forecasts by 25% in FY’17 and 22%25% in FY’18’19 respectively. Escrow continues to perform in line with expectations. In response to these issues the Board has announced a strategic review into all of the Assurance businesses. The results of the strategic review are expected to be announced at the FY results in July. With an extended period of uncertainty on the horizon we believe it will be hard for investors to gain confidence in NCC in the short term. That said we see fundamental value in the stock. Escrow is unaffected by this warning and remains an extremely high quality business, which we value at £353m in our SOTP. At the current share price this leaves Assurance valued at c.5x cal’17 EBITDA. While this appears to be an attractive multiple for a rare cybersecurity asset, we would like further clarity on the underlying nature of the current issues, hence our Hold recommendation. Our 138p target price assumes a 12x EBITDA multiple for Assurance but we apply a 20% discount to the group to account for the current uncertainty.

BE12:02pm

Timeline leading to this announcement
10th August CFO previous Atul Patel announced his intention to resign
20th August First trading update signalling Assurance contract issues, retaining guidance with consensus EBITDA at £55m at this time
13th December Further trading update with downgraded guidance to adjusted EBITDA range of £45.5m to £47.5m
11th January Announcement that Brian Tenner will take up CFO role on the 1st February
19th January Interim Results reiterating guidance and outlook, Chairman to step down at end of financial yearn

Imagine how bad things would be if it wasn't in the go-go growth business of cyber warfare

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

Review of Strategy
NCC’s board is initiating a comprehensive review of the operating strategy, including reviews of all Assurance businesses. We had previously noted that with Chairman of 17 years due to step down, the board of NCC was somewhat light. In our opinion, the role of the senior independent director, Debbie Hewitt is now crucial in the direction the company takes in the immediate future. Quoting the statement (with our emphasis):
“In addition, given that the significant and planned rise in central and divisional operating costs this financial year has not produced the anticipated improvement in sales, there will also be a review of how the assets and resources of the Group can be more efficiently deployed and utilised.”

Vulnerable to corporate action and possible takeover
We note that the board is to appoint external consultants to lead the strategic review. In addition to placing CEO Rob Cotton’s position under heavy scrutiny, we believe this statement raises the possibility of corporate restructuring (including asset sales). We believe disposals, breakup of the group or indeed a full sale may come under consideration.

Forecast Changes
We retain our expectations for the performance of Escrow, so all revision relate to Assurance and the impact of downgrades on the balance sheet. We reduce our group revenue for FY2017F from £244m to £218m (a 11% downgrade), our adjusted EBITDA forecast falls 30% from £47m to £33m. Adjusted PBT falls from £36.5m to £22.6m, with Adjusted EPS of 6.2p representing a 35% downgrade. We forecast a reported LBT of £44m from our previous £20m of profit, reflecting write downs on the goodwill and acquisition intangibles of the Fox-IT and Accumuli acquisitions. Our net debt forecast for the year falls to £41m, reflecting our belief that c£22m in contingent consideration is now unlikely to be paid.

We downgrade our recommendation to Hold, with our view that the company is coming into play and justifies keeping NCC off the buy list. We await further reaction in the share price and commentary from the board.

NCC Group PLC (NCC:LSE): Last: 96.00, down 30.5 (-24.11%), High: 108.00, Low: 88.00, Volume: 20.76m
